description.narrative: Syftet med projektet är att skapa en process i vilken ISSC i samverkan med sina regionala partners can utforma ett framtida Globalt Forsknings och Koordinerings Initiative om kliamtförändringar för samhällsvetenskaperna. Projektet skall resultera i en ansökan från ISSC om stöd till ett sådant långsiktigt intiative. Den bör ta upp agenda, policy, och mekanismer för koordinering o finansiering.

The aim of the project is to create a process by which ISSC in collaboration with regional partners can design a future Global Research and Coordination Initiative on climate change for the social sciences. The project will result in an application from ISSC for such a long-term initiative. It will address research agenda setting, policy interface, and mechanisms for global coordination and funding.

General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The WSSF-programme’s overall outcomes:
From 2012 to 2015, the International Social Science Council (ISSC), with support from Sida, led an international scientific programme designed to nurture a new generation of social scientists to help solve pressing global problems – and particularly those that affect low- and middle-income countries most urgently.
During this period, the World Social Science (WSS) Fellows programme, referred to as “Early-career Excellence: the World Social Science Fellows Programme”, selected 217 early career scientists from around the world to participate in a series of seminars, conferences and networking events that tackled the burning societal issues facing the world: sustainability, urbanization, global social governance and the green economy, among others. The events aimed to examine these issues and set an agenda for research and action. They identified research trends, gaps and priorities at the global level, with the aim of fostering new international research collaborations to respond to these priorities and fill in the gaps. Through these activities and Fellowships, the programme’s overall aim was to foster innovative research by excellent early-career scientists from all parts of the world.
Over 1,600 eligible applications were received and evaluated for the WSS Fellows programme’s various activities. To be eligible, candidates had to be working at a postdoctoral level, preferably within five years after completing their PhD, but without yet holding a ’tenure track’ or permanent position. They also needed to have a strong record of research publications. Of the eligible candidates, 217 (13.5%) were selected to take part. Strong efforts were made to secure the participation of early-career scientists from low- to middle-income countries and of the 217 Fellows who took part in the programme, 48 per cent were working in such countries. Gender equality was imperative for ensuring that the programme was fully representative, and 53 per cent of the Fellows selected were women.
The WSS Fellows seminars saw an increased attention to research addressing strategic policy issues, with policy-related stakeholders and practitioners participating and playing a key role in all seminars.
The Fellows initiated creation of the Trans-Urban Knowledge Network (TUKN), a global network of Fellows working on sustainable urbanisation, launched in 2016. This has resulted in an active and self-sustaining international network of Fellows.
Some concrete outputs of the WSSF programme 2013-2016
Statistics for the total number of 217 Fellows (2013-2016) participating in Sida supported WSS Fellows events (excluding the Future Earth Young Scientists Networking Conferences) include 50% women and 65% fellows from middle and lower income countries (50% MIC, 15% LIC).
Publications and contributions by the WSS Fellows: - 20 chapters in book publications (open access supported through additional Sida funds); - 41 published peer-reviewed publications (incl. 19 in 2016) + 2 monographs (in 2016); - 74 referenced Blogs
Highlights of results and outputs for 2015-2016 :
• The two 2015 WSSF seminars saw an increased attention to research addressing strategic policy issues, with policy stakeholders playing a key role in the events. This includes the successful nomination of four Fellows to participate in the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) assessments.
• 70 new Fellows entering the programme in 2015 through their participation in three ISSC seminars, with 59% women and 51% from lower and middle income countries (LMIC).
• 6 new hosts and 5 new relationships were established with expert convenors/partners regarding in-kind support:
1. Sustainable Urbanisation Seminar, September 2015, Durban. It was organised in partnership with the Cities Alliance, and hosted by the Municipal Institute of Learning (MILE) of et Thekwini Municipality and the University of KwaZulu Natal.
2. The Big Data in an Urban Context seminar, November – December 2015, Xiamen, China. It was organised in partnership with CODATA, an interdisciplinary Scientific Committee of the International Council for Science (ICSU). The seminar was hosted by the International Programme Office on Urban Health and Wellbeing at the Institute of Urban Environment (IUE) in Xiamen, China.
3. The 3rd Future Earth Young Scientist Networking Conference on Integrated Science, entitled “Future Sustainability: the role of science in the Sustainable Development Goals”, held from 24-30 May 2015 at Villa Vigoni, Italy, was organised in collaboration with: ICSU, DFG and Future Earth.
One of the most substantial outcomes in during the reporting year was the launch of the World Social Science Report 2016 centered around the theme "Inequalities and Social Justice" and the implications for knowledge resource production and distribution in the world.
